name: Pannfisch with Fried Potatoes and Mustard Sauce
ingredients: 2 kg medium firm potatoes; 2 bunches spring onions; 10 medium mushrooms; 1600 g fish fillets (e.g., cod, pollock, haddock, or redfish); 6 tbsp lemon juice; 300 g butter; 160 g mustard; 4 egg yolks; 300 g natural yogurt; salt; pepper; 2 splashes lemon juice; oil or clarified butter; flour; parsley, dill, or herbs of choice, chopped
preparation: Boil the potatoes in salted water as jacket potatoes. Clean and slice the spring onions and mushrooms. Wash, dry, and cut fish fillets into 16 pieces, drizzle with 3 tbsp lemon juice. For the mustard sauce, melt 150 g butter over low heat, warm mustard and egg yolks over a water bath while whisking, gradually add melted butter until slightly thickened, then stir in yogurt. Season with salt, pepper, and lemon juice and keep warm. Peel and slice potatoes, fry in hot oil or clarified butter until golden, add spring onions and mushrooms, cook 3 more minutes. Coat fish with flour, salt, and pepper, fry in a separate pan about 3 minutes per side. Serve fried potatoes topped with fish, sprinkle with fresh herbs, and serve with mustard sauce.

name: Labskaus with Matjes and Fried Egg
ingredients: 4 kg potatoes; 300 g pickled gherkins; 400 g beetroot (from jar); 200 ml milk; 4 cans corned beef (340 g each, not cured); 8 eggs; 8 matjes fillets; 400 g butter or margarine; 400 g breadcrumbs; 4 onions, sliced; salt; pepper
preparation: Peel and boil potatoes in salted water until soft. Dice gherkins and beetroot, slice onions, and prepare eggs, butter, and breadcrumbs. Mash the cooked potatoes with corned beef, season with salt and pepper, then fold in gherkins and beetroot, keeping some pieces whole. Fry the eggs sunny-side up and toast breadcrumbs in butter. Serve the mashed mixture topped with fried eggs, toasted breadcrumbs, and matjes fillets.

name: Cod with Vegetables, Potatoes, and Mustard Sauce
ingredients: 3 kg whole cod; 2 kg small firm potatoes; 3 liters dry white wine; 800 g carrots; 800 g leeks; 120 g mushrooms; 80 g fennel; 120 g celery; 4 untreated lemons; 1 bunch parsley; 1 bunch chervil; 1 bunch dill; 6 shallots; 10 garlic cloves; 8 tbsp butter; 6 sprigs lemon thyme; 2 jars vegetable stock; 2 cups sweet cream; 2 tbsp flour; 6 tbsp Dijon mustard; salt; pepper
preparation: Clean and roughly chop celery, fennel, and mushrooms. Finely dice shallots and garlic, chop lemon thyme. Sauté shallots, garlic, vegetables, and thyme in 2 tbsp butter, sprinkle with flour, then deglaze with vegetable stock and reduce by half. Add cream and lemon juice, bring to a boil, season with salt and pepper, blend until smooth, strain if desired, stir in mustard, and keep warm. Peel, wash, and boil potatoes. Slice remaining lemons. Rinse and dry fish, cut into four pieces. Bring 2 liters water, 2 tsp salt, white wine, and lemon slices to a simmer, cook fish gently for 17 minutes. Julienne carrots and leeks, sauté with 2 tbsp butter for 5 minutes, season with salt and pepper. Chop parsley, dill, and chervil. Drain potatoes and fish, plate with vegetables, pour mustard sauce over fish, and garnish with chopped herbs.

name: Kale with Grützwurst
ingredients: 2 kg frozen kale; 2.67 medium onions; 400 g smoked belly bacon; 1.33 tbsp lard, goose fat, or clarified butter; 8 cooking sausages/Mettenden; 10.67 Pinkel sausages (Grützpinkel); 1066.67 g Kasseler (neck or lean pork); 1.33 cubes meat broth; lukewarm water; salt; pepper; 1.33 tsp mustard; 1.33 pinch sugar
preparation: Dice onions and sauté in fat until golden, add large pieces of bacon and briefly fry. Rinse and drain kale, add to onions and bacon with lukewarm water and meat broth cube, simmer gently. Add two Grützpinkel sausages with casings, cover, simmer, then remove casings and stir filling into kale. Add mustard and Kasseler, simmer gently, stirring occasionally and adjusting seasoning. Place Mettenden/cooking sausages on top, continue simmering. Best if cooled overnight and slowly reheated. Serve with boiled potatoes.

name: Finkenwerder-Style Plaice with Bacon Topping
ingredients: 4 plaice or 2 plaice fillets; 800 g onions; 800 g bacon; flour for dusting; 12 tbsp butter; 8 tbsp chopped parsley; lemons for serving; oil
preparation: If using whole fish, fillet by removing the backbone, tail, and head, then cut fillets close to the bones. Dust fillets with flour and pan-fry in oil, skin-side first, for 2–3 minutes per side. In a separate pan, sauté onions and bacon until onions are translucent and bacon is crispy, then add a piece of butter. Add a piece of butter to the fish and drizzle melted butter over fillets. Chop parsley and mix into the bacon-onion topping, then spread over the fish and serve. Serve with fried potatoes.

name: Kale with Kasseler
ingredients: 1400 g kale; 2 onions; 60 g clarified butter; salt; 500 ml vegetable broth; 200 ml apple juice; 8 Mettenden sausages; 4 slices pork belly; 2 kg Kasseler neck; 6 tbsp oats; pepper; 6 tbsp hot mustard
preparation: Strip kale from ribs, wash thoroughly, boil 10 minutes, drain, rinse, squeeze out excess water, and chop coarsely. Slice onions. Heat butter, sauté onions 2 minutes, add kale and sauté 2 more minutes. Add broth, apple juice, and meat pieces, simmer 25 minutes. Stir in oats, cook 2 more minutes, season with salt and pepper, and mix in mustard.

name: Beef Roulade with Apple Red Cabbage and Mashed Potatoes
ingredients: 8 beef roulades; 16 pickles; 320 g Dijon mustard; 24 slices bacon; 3.2 onions; 3.2 tbsp clarified butter; salt; pepper; 800 g soup vegetables; 3.2 onions; 3.2 tbsp clarified butter; 1.6 tbsp sugar; 800 ml red wine; 3.2 tsp tomato paste; 640 ml beef stock; 80 g butter; salt; pepper; 1.6 kg red cabbage; 3.2 apples; 3.2 tbsp sugar; 3.2 tbsp balsamic vinegar; 400 ml water; 160 ml red wine; 1.6 onions; 0.8 tsp ground cloves; 3.2 bay leaves; 4.8 tbsp clarified butter; 1.6 kg starchy potatoes; 160 g butter; nutmeg; 240 ml cream; salt; pepper
preparation: This recipe takes a lot of time. Slice pickles and onions. Season roulades with salt and pepper, spread mustard on one side, top with bacon, onion rings, and pickles, fold and roll tightly, secure with skewers. Brown roulades in clarified butter, remove from pan. Dice soup vegetables and onions, sauté 10 minutes in 2 tbsp butter, add tomato paste and sugar, gradually add red wine, reduce, then add beef stock, bring to boil, return roulades, simmer covered for 2 hours, turning occasionally and basting with sauce. Remove roulades, strain sauce, return to pan, stir in butter, reheat, return roulades for 15 minutes. Prepare red cabbage by removing outer leaves, quartering, removing core, finely slicing. Grate apples, dice onions, sauté in butter with sugar, add cabbage, vinegar, cook 10 minutes, add water, wine, bay leaves, cloves, salt, simmer 40 minutes. For mashed potatoes, peel and cube potatoes, boil 30 minutes, drain, mash with butter and cream, season with nutmeg, salt, and pepper. Serve roulades with apple red cabbage and mashed potatoes.

name: Hamburg-Style Pannfisch
ingredients: 800 g firm potatoes; 500 g fish fillets (e.g., pollock, cod, or haddock); flour for coating; salt; pepper; lemon juice; 1 tbsp butter; 5 tbsp neutral oil; 1 small leek (white part); 30 g butter; 25 g flour; 250 ml fish stock or vegetable broth; 50 ml cream; 2 tbsp Dijon mustard; salt; pepper; optional lemon juice
preparation: Cut fish fillets into sticks, season with lemon juice, salt, and pepper, chill. Boil potatoes 20 minutes, drain, cool, peel, and slice. For sauce, quarter leek lengthwise, slice crosswise, melt butter, stir in flour until smooth, gradually add stock and cream, add leek, simmer, stir in mustard, season with salt, pepper, and optional lemon juice. Heat 3 tbsp oil and 1 tbsp butter, sauté onions, add potato slices, fry until crispy, keep warm. Lightly coat fish in flour, fry 3–4 minutes until crispy, keep warm. Serve fried potatoes topped with fish, pour sauce around, optionally with cucumber or leaf salad. For best results, cook potatoes the day before so they dry slightly, and prepare sauce first, keeping it warm while frying potatoes and fish.

name: Spaghetti Bolognese
ingredients: 166.67 g butter; olive oil, a small amount; 2.67 large onions; 4 carrots; 4 celery stalks; 1.33 kg ground beef; white wine, a splash; milk, as needed (approx. 250–500 ml depending on sauce quantity); 2 cans tomatoes (400 g each); 4 garlic cloves, sliced; 4 chili peppers, crushed; sea salt; freshly ground black pepper; 800 g spaghetti / pasta
preparation: The most important part of a proper Bolognese is the soffritto. Melt a generous amount of butter together with a little olive oil in a pan to prevent the butter from burning. Clean and peel the onions, carrots, and celery, then finely chop them. Cook the vegetables gently over very low heat for at least 30 minutes, stirring occasionally, until soft, translucent, and aromatic. The vegetables should sweat slowly and must not brown. In a separate pan, sear the ground beef over high heat until it develops a deep color. Deglaze with a splash of white wine, scraping up any browned bits from the pan. Depending on the amount of sauce, add about 250–500 ml of milk, which will mellow the flavor of the meat. Once the mixture comes to a gentle boil, add the canned tomatoes. Tomatoes similar to San Marzano are ideal due to their natural sweetness. When the sauce begins to simmer again, stir in the prepared soffritto. Add the sliced garlic and crushed chili peppers, then season with sea salt and freshly ground black pepper. Let the sauce simmer gently for as long as possible—ideally about 5 hours, but at least 2 hours. Add a little water or light broth occasionally if needed to prevent sticking. Cook the spaghetti in salted water according to package instructions and serve with the Bolognese sauce.

name: Italian Pizza
ingredients: Dough: 500 ml lukewarm water; 25 ml olive oil; 40 g fresh yeast; 20 g salt; 1 pinch sugar; 925 g all-purpose flour; any toppings you like
preparation: Dissolve the yeast together with the salt and sugar in the lukewarm water and olive oil. Add the flour and knead into a smooth dough. Let the dough rise in a warm place for about 30 minutes, then knead again. Cover and refrigerate the dough for up to 2 days to allow it to develop flavor. The dough is sufficient for about 6 round pizzas. Shape and bake the pizzas as desired. Top with tomato sauce, cheese, and any toppings you like.

name: Coq au Vin – Chicken in Wine with Oven-Roasted Herbs
ingredients: 4 chickens; 16 garlic cloves; 8 onions; 16 tbsp olive oil; 8 sprigs rosemary; 16 sprigs thyme; 1 liter dry white wine; salt; freshly ground black pepper; 2.2kg potatoes
preparation: Cut each chicken into 4–6 pieces, wash, and place them in a shallow baking dish. Brush the chicken pieces generously with olive oil on all sides and season well with salt and pepper. Peel the garlic cloves and cut them in half. Peel and quarter the onions. Arrange the onions, garlic, and herbs around the chicken pieces and pour in the white wine. Roast in a preheated oven at 200 °C (390 °F) using top and bottom heat for about 1 hour and 15 minutes, basting occasionally with the cooking juices and adding more wine if necessary. Serve with potatoes.

name: Ratatouille
ingredients: 2 medium eggplants; 4 medium zucchinis; 4 large red bell peppers; 4 large yellow bell peppers; 2 large cans peeled tomatoes; 2 large vegetable onions; 8 garlic cloves; 2 tsp fresh rosemary, finely chopped; 2 tbsp fresh thyme, finely chopped; 2 tbsp fresh sage, finely chopped; 1 tsp dried lavender flowers, crushed; 2 heaped tsp sugar; 200 ml olive oil; sea salt; freshly ground black pepper; 1 tube tomato paste, 3-4 baguettes
preparation: Wash and prepare all vegetables and cut them into bite-sized pieces. Roughly dice the onions and finely chop the garlic. Wash and finely chop the herbs. Salt the eggplant pieces and let them rest for at least 10 minutes, then pat them dry thoroughly. Heat the olive oil in a large, high-sided pan. Fry the onions and zucchinis first, then add the bell peppers, and finally the eggplants. Sauté everything vigorously for about 5 minutes. Stir in the tomato paste and season with salt and pepper. Add the garlic, herbs, peeled tomatoes, and sugar. Reduce the heat to medium and let the ratatouille simmer for about 20 minutes, adding a little water if necessary. The vegetables should be tender but still slightly firm. Serve simply with fresh baguette.

name: Cottage Pie
ingredients: 2 kg floury potatoes; 1.33 bunch soup vegetables (carrots, celery, leek); 2.67 medium onions; 2.67 garlic cloves; 1.33 kg ground beef; 2.67 tbsp oil; 1.33 tbsp tomato paste; 1.33 tsp granulated vegetable stock; 400 ml milk; 1.33 tbsp butter; 0.33 liter water; salt; freshly ground black pepper; paprika powder; ground nutmeg
preparation: Peel, wash, and dice the potatoes. Cook them in salted water for about 20 minutes until tender. Meanwhile, clean and prepare the soup vegetables; slice the carrots and finely dice the remaining vegetables. Peel and finely chop the onions and garlic. Heat the oil in a large pan and fry the ground beef until crumbly. Season with salt, pepper, and paprika. Add the onions, garlic, and soup vegetables and sauté briefly. Stir in the tomato paste and let it cook for a moment. Deglaze with about 250 ml of water, bring to a boil, then stir in the granulated vegetable stock. Simmer for 8–10 minutes and adjust seasoning. Drain the potatoes and mash them. Stir in the milk and butter and season with salt, pepper, and nutmeg. Transfer the meat mixture to a greased baking dish and spread the mashed potatoes evenly on top. Bake in a preheated oven at 200 °C (fan: 170 °C) for about 20 minutes until lightly golden.

name: Roast Beef with Yorkshire Pudding
ingredients: 166.67 ml milk; 5.33 eggs; 333.33 g flour; 1.33 pinches salt; 1.33 pinches ground nutmeg; 1.33 tbsp lard; 1.33 pinches white pepper; 1.6 kg roast beef; 0.67 tsp black pepper; 1.33 tbsp Worcestershire sauce; 2.67 tbsp dry sherry; 0.67 tsp green peppercorns, crushed; 5.33 tbsp oil; 1.33 tsp salt
preparation: Bring the milk to a boil, then allow it to cool completely. Whisk the eggs, sift the flour over them, and beat vigorously until smooth. Gradually stir in the milk. Season the batter with salt, white pepper, and nutmeg, cover, and let rest in the refrigerator for 1 hour. Rinse the roast beef and pat dry. Score the fat cap in a diamond pattern using a sharp knife, taking care not to cut into the meat. This allows the fat to render and drip onto the pudding during roasting. Mix the black pepper with Worcestershire sauce, sherry, crushed green peppercorns, and oil. Rub the meat with this marinade, cover, and let marinate for 30 minutes, turning occasionally. Preheat the oven to 250 °C using top and bottom heat. Grease the roasting rack with oil and rinse the drip pan with water. Pat the roast beef dry, rub with salt, and place it on the roasting rack on the middle oven rack. Slide the drip pan onto the lower rack and roast for 15 minutes. Meanwhile, stir the Yorkshire pudding batter once more. Heat the lard and mix it with the drippings in the drip pan. Pour in the batter, smooth it out, return the pan to the oven, and bake the Yorkshire pudding beneath the roast beef. After 10 minutes, reduce the temperature to 200 °C (390 °F) and continue cooking for another 15 minutes. Remove the roast beef and let it rest on a warmed platter in the switched-off oven for 10 minutes. Slice the Yorkshire pudding into strips and the roast beef into thin slices.

name: Swedish Summer Fish Soup
ingredients: 6 large potatoes; 2 leeks; 4 tbsp butter; 1.5 liters vegetable stock; 400 g salmon fillet; 200 ml cream; 6 tbsp fresh dill, finely chopped
preparation: Wash, peel, and dice the potatoes. Wash the leeks and slice them into rings. Melt the butter in a pot and lightly sauté the potatoes and leeks. Add the vegetable stock and cook for about 15 minutes until the vegetables are tender. If desired, briefly purée the soup with an immersion blender using just a few pulses. Cut the salmon into bite-sized cubes and add them to the soup. Let the soup gently steep for another 5 minutes without boiling. Stir in the cream, sprinkle with fresh dill, and serve hot.

name: Köttbullar in Cream Sauce with Lingonberries
ingredients: 1000 g mixed ground meat; 2 eggs; 4 tbsp breadcrumbs; 250 ml heavy cream; salt; freshly ground black pepper; 4 tbsp oil; 4 tsp pan gravy stock; 6 tbsp dark roux; 8 tsp lingonberry preserves
preparation: Mix the ground meat with the eggs, breadcrumbs, and 2 tablespoons of cream until well combined. Season with salt and pepper and shape into about 25 small meatballs. Heat the oil in a pan and fry the meatballs until browned all over. Remove and set aside. Pour about 375 ml water and the remaining cream into the pan. Add the pan gravy stock and bring to a boil. Stir in the dark roux and cook for about one minute. Season the sauce with salt and pepper to taste. Return the meatballs to the sauce and heat through. Serve with lingonberry preserves; Traditionally served with potatoes in any form (boiled, mashed, or roasted).

name: Klopsiki in Dill Sauce – Polish Style Meatballs
ingredients: 1600 g mixed ground meat; 4 eggs; 2 bunches fresh dill; 2 bunches fresh parsley; 2 large onions; 8 garlic cloves; 12 tbsp wheat flour; 2 tsp salt; 4 tsp paprika powder; freshly ground black pepper; 1000 ml vegetable stock; oil, for frying; 140 g butter; 400 g cream; 20 large potatoes
preparation: Dice the onions finely and sauté them gently in a little oil until translucent. Place the ground meat in a large bowl and add 2 eggs, the finely chopped parsley, the finely chopped or pressed garlic, salt, paprika powder, and black pepper. Add the sautéed onions and knead everything into a smooth mixture. Fold in about 2 tablespoons of flour. Shape the mixture into meatballs using about one tablespoon per ball. Bring the vegetable stock to a boil in a medium-sized pot and gently cook the raw meatballs for about 6 minutes, making sure they are fully submerged. Remove them with a slotted spoon and repeat until all meatballs are cooked. Melt the butter in a pan, whisk in 4 tablespoons of flour, then gradually add some of the vegetable stock while stirring constantly. Bring briefly to a boil, add the cream, and simmer on low heat. Finely chop the dill and stir it into the sauce. Add the cooked meatballs, cover, and let everything gently steep for another 5–10 minutes. Meanwhile, peel, wash, and boil the potatoes. Serve the meatballs with dill sauce and potatoes.

name: Cabbage Rolls – Polish Go??bki
ingredients: 1333.33 g mixed ground meat; 2.67 heads white cabbage with large leaves; 8 tbsp tomato paste; 8 tbsp ketchup; 666.67 g rice; 5.33 medium onions; 2.67 tsp granulated meat stock; 2.67 packs smoked bacon (raw, not cooked); salt; freshly ground black pepper; Maggi seasoning; flour, for thickening; water, as needed; oil, for frying
preparation: Cut out the hard core of the cabbage with a knife, creating a small opening. Place the cabbage in a large pot, pour hot water over it, cover, and let it simmer gently over very low heat for a few minutes, turning occasionally so the leaves soften evenly. Once softened, carefully separate the cabbage leaves. For the filling, place about 500 g of the ground meat into a bowl. Cook the rice in salted water until partially cooked, about 10–12 minutes, then drain and let cool. Dice the onions and fry them gently in hot oil until golden but not browned. Add the rice and fried onions to the meat, season with salt and pepper, and mix thoroughly by hand until homogeneous. Place 2–3 tablespoons of filling onto each cabbage leaf, fold in the sides, and roll tightly to form cabbage rolls. Heat a pan and line the bottom completely with the smoked bacon. Fry the bacon until crisp, then place the cabbage rolls tightly next to each other on top. Pour in about 250 ml of meat stock—enough to cover the rolls halfway. Cover and simmer over medium heat for 1 to 1.5 hours, turning carefully several times so they cook evenly. Remove the rolls from the pan (the bacon can be discarded if desired). Season the remaining broth with tomato paste, ketchup, Maggi seasoning, and additional stock if needed. If the sauce is too thin, thicken it with flour mixed with cold water, stirring it into the boiling liquid. Return the cabbage rolls to the sauce and heat through before serving.
